16.79.text: I resisted. It looks fantastic though.

Well now, what a day we're having, 
absolutely inspirational, fantastic.

25.39.text:
I saw Romeo Dallaire remark 
on these geese earlier on,

32.33.text:
and I considered these geese, 
Canada geese.

35.86.text: They're all over the world, you know.

40.14.text:

50.87.text: The Shakespeare we're enormously familiar with,

53.38.text:
but the Shakespeare 
that we know and we don't know.

58.15.text:
And of course, every day, we're quoting 
Shakespeare but we don't know it.

64.86.text:
Shakespeare –
We don't know a great deal about the man.

68.29.text:
What we know about him 
is generally through his works.

72.84.text: He was a man, just like you and me,

76.98.text:
he lived his life, felt great joy 
and great sadness,

85.79.text:
In Canada – talk about 
Shakespeare surrounding us –

90.73.text:
we have the Stratford Shakespeare Festival 
in Ontario,

93.70.text:
that's the biggest theatre festival, 
I might add, in North America.

103.63.text:
We have Bard on the Beach Shakespeare 
here in Vancouver.

106.24.text:
We've got Shakespeare festivals in between. 
In America,

111.60.text: lots of Shakespeare's festivals through America.

114.48.text: You have The Globe in London,

116.52.text:
and, of course, The Royal Shakespeare Company 
in Stratford-upon-Avon.

122.73.text:
So, Shakespeare is alive and well, but 
since you leapt out of bed this morning,

128.91.text: and you've had this wonderful day here,

131.32.text: I'm sure most of you are very much unaware

134.74.text: that you've been quoting Shakespeare all day.

138.90.text: Let me give you a bunch of examples.

142.04.text:
First of all, I want you to do something 
for a change.

146.15.text: When I point at you and beckon you on,

148.60.text:
I want you to say, 
"Quoting Shakespeare".

152.33.text:
Now, come on, 
with all that energy from the Pop-Tarts,

158.76.text:
That's pretty good. 
Once more, even louder

163.74.text:
If you cannot understand my argument 
and declare, "It's Greek to me", you are...

171.74.text:
If you claim to be,
"More sinned against than sinning", you are...

177.53.text:
If you, 
"Recall your salad days", you are...

183.19.text:
If you act more in sorrow than in anger, 
if your wish is father to the thought,

188.02.text:
if your lost property has vanished
into thin air, you are...

194.54.text:
If you've ever refused to budge an inch 
or suffered from green-eyed jealousy,

199.01.text:
if you've been played fast and loose,
been tongue-tied, a tower of strength,

206.45.text:
if you have knitted your brows, 
made a virtue of necessity,

210.80.text: insisted on fair play, slept not one wink,

215.21.text:
stood on ceremony, danced attendance 
on your lord and master,

220.59.text:
laughed yourself into stitches,
had short shrift, cold comfort

226.37.text: or too much of a good thing.

229.68.text:
If you've seen better days 
or lived in a fool's paradise,

233.20.text:
why, be that as it may, 
the more fool you,

236.37.text:
for it is a foregone conclusion 
that you are,

239.54.text: as good luck would have it...

242.81.text:
If you think it is early days 
and clear out bag and baggage,

246.35.text: if you think it is high time

247.97.text:
and that that is the long and the short of it, 
if you believe that the game is up

253.10.text:
and that truth will out even if it involves 
your own flesh and blood,

257.18.text:
if you lie low till the crack of doom
because you suspect foul play,

263.13.text:
if you have your teeth set on edge 
at one fell swoop without rhyme or reason,

268.98.text: then, to give the devil his due,

271.24.text:
if the truth were known -- for surely you have 
a tongue in your head, you are...

278.17.text:
Even if you bid me good riddance 
and send me packing,

282.76.text: if you wish I was as dead as a door-nail,

286.42.text:
if you think I am an eyesore, a laughing stock, 
the devil incarnate,

291.93.text:
a stony-hearted villain, bloody-minded
or a blinking idiot, then, by Jove!

298.89.text:
O Lord! Tut, tut! For goodness' sake! 
What the dickens!

303.09.text:
But me no buts - 
it's all one to me, for you are...

324.96.text:
Let's look at the private man 
that I alluded to a moment ago.

334.76.text:
the playwright in London, 
the producer, the actor.

342.13.text:
There's a gorgeous little sonnet. 
A sonnet is a 14 line poem,

347.91.text: and Shakespeare wrote over 150 of those.

352.93.text:
And this particular one – it's perhaps 
one of the best known pieces of poetry,

359.08.text: I think, probably in the world –

360.50.text: "Shall I Compare Thee to a Summer's Day".

364.30.text: Now generally this little piece of poetry

367.28.text:
is said, or recited, or written down,
for great occasions,

379.36.text:
But there's a theory that in fact, 
nestling inside this poetry,

384.00.text:
if you think of it another way, Shakespeare, 
we didn't know,

387.68.text: and the mystery that surrounds all that,

391.55.text:
that in fact, 
this little sonnet was a eulogy.

398.21.text:
Shakespeare had 3 children, 
one of them was a son.

404.09.text: His little boy was called Hamnet,

407.34.text: not Hamlet, this one is H-A-M-N-E-T.

411.82.text:
The other one H-A-M-L-E-T 
is a very good play he wrote. (Laughter)

417.04.text: But his son was called Hamnet

420.88.text:
and he got word, 
when he was working away in London,

428.70.text:
Now, here's the man, 
the man like you and me,

433.00.text: living his life and now crisis hits.

439.51.text:
And of course he has to go. 
He has to go from London.

442.71.text:
If we were to drive from central London 
to Stratford-upon-Avon now,

449.11.text:
where his family were, that would probably take us, 
if we had a good run, a little over 90 minutes.

454.89.text: But in those days, it was 3 days!

458.13.text:
So, Shakespeare took off 
and he got there,

463.13.text: and when he got to Stratford,

465.36.text: he was met by his family

467.83.text:
and he found out 
that his son was dead, buried.

474.76.text: There was nothing left to do.

478.16.text:
But, what could he do
apart from comfort his family?

482.87.text:
But to survive it, 
what was he going to do?

490.79.text:
I like to imagine that perhaps, 
after everyone had gone to bed,

495.91.text: he stayed up, with a candle and his quill pen.

502.14.text:
And he wrote and he did 
what Shakespeare could do best of all.

508.93.text:
Through words, 
he could express his feelings.

513.54.text:
And I like to think he wrote this little poem 
"Shall I Compare Thee to a Summer's Day",

518.37.text: and he talks about eternity in the poem,

520.63.text:
and as long as men can breathe 
and eyes can see, this lives forever.

524.80.text:
That this froze little Hamnet
in time in his mind,

529.49.text: to be an immortal in Shakespeare's lifetime.

534.65.text: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?

538.70.text: Thou art more lovely and more temperate.

544.00.text: Rough winds do break the darling buds of May,

547.97.text: And summer's lease hath all too short a date.

552.07.text: Sometimes too hot the eye of heaven shines,

556.84.text: And often is his gold complexion dimmed;

561.68.text: And every fair from fair sometime declines,

564.75.text: By chance, or nature's changing course, untrimmed;

571.62.text: But thy eternal summer shall not fade,

578.51.text: Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow'st,

583.32.text: Nor shall Death brag thou wand'rest in his shade,

587.79.text: When in eternal lines to Time thou grow'st.

594.00.text: So long as men can breathe, or eyes can see,

601.06.text: So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.

611.88.text: A eulogy? I don't know. It's beautiful.

616.95.text:
There's a mystery about it, as there is
about so much of Shakespeare,

622.77.text: and I think that's part of the magic of it all.

627.48.text: Now is the winter of our discontent.

632.01.text: How is the winter of our discontent?

635.54.text:
My goodness gracious! 
Look at Europe right now.

641.31.text:
Occupy Wall Street, 
occupy everywhere else...

660.60.text:
when there's so much going on 
in the world,

664.02.text: and it's all so deeply complicated,

666.39.text:
this is a time, I think, that if we could skip back, 
skip forward 400 years

674.05.text:
This is a time for great initiative, 
great inspiration, great leadership.

680.82.text:
This is time for heroes, I think, 
to help to show us the way.

687.60.text: Shakespeare was rich in heroes too.

691.10.text:
Look at Henry V –
We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.

700.32.text:
"Now is the winter of our discontent." 
Who was that?

703.13.text:
Richard, Duke of Gloucester. 
It's the opening line of Richard III.

707.86.text: Richard III, what does he want?

711.69.text:
He wants trouble. 
He wants trouble and he doesn't care.

715.95.text:
He's willing to risk everything. 
Talk about being bold!

720.90.text:
His elder brother is the king, 
there's another brother in between.

724.11.text:
The king, he has two prince sons.
So Richard, Duke of Gloucester,

728.36.text:
the younger brother,
is never going to be king!

734.68.text:
But he's gonna force that.
And he tells us all about it.

738.50.text:
of the top of Richard III, 
malevolent, dangerous,

745.20.text: but nevertheless, we as an audience,

751.08.text:
we become complicit
in his dreadful plans.

757.85.text:
And it's the most extraordinary feeling,
sitting in the audience watching him,

761.05.text:
Richard, lay waste to all these people,
and sitting there thinking,

766.27.text:
"Yes! Yes! Yes!"
It's an awful feeling.

772.58.text: Richard III, deformed, as he calls himself.

777.62.text:
The traditional withered left side, 
the crook back,

782.38.text: "Now is the winter of our discontent.

785.72.text: Made glorious summer by this son of York;

792.49.text: And all the clouds that low'r'd upon our house.

796.54.text: In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.

802.63.text: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;

805.40.text: Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;

807.84.text: Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,

811.29.text: Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.

818.66.text: Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;

823.78.text: And now, instead of mounting barbed steeds

826.59.text: To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,

829.45.text: He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber

835.02.text: To the lascivious pleasings of a lute.

841.43.text: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,

846.60.text: Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;

850.53.text: I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty

856.71.text: To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;

860.33.text: I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion,

864.31.text: Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,

869.20.text: Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time

876.09.text: Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,

880.14.text: And that so lamely and unfashionable

882.45.text: That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;

887.12.text: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover,

893.41.text: To entertain these fair well-spoken days,

900.03.text: I am determined to prove a villain

903.74.text: And hate the idle pleasures of these days.

912.42.text: It has been a hard day's night

923.91.text:
and I've been working like a dog!
(Laughter)

927.56.text: It's been a hard day's night

929.66.text: and I should be sleeping like a log!

933.53.text:
But when I get home to you,
I find the things that you do

957.48.text:
So that, perhaps, was the Shakespeare
you did not know.
